question: Question_07_(e)
statement:
Let $f(x) = x^2 - 6x$ and let \emph{P} be the point (4, -12).

(e) Sketch the curve $y = f(x)$, the point \emph{P}, and the lines whose
slopes you found in part
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/December_2011/Question_07_(d)}{(d)}.
sols:
\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $f(x) = x^2 - 6x$
\end{itemize}

As suggested in the hint, first find the roots of the function.

$x^2 - 6x = 0$

$x(x-6) = 0$

$f(x)$ has roots at \emph{x = 0} and \emph{x = 6}. Using this fact, or
by calculating where the derivative of $f$ is zero, we can deduce that
the minimum of $f(x)$ is at \emph{x = 3}. To find the y-value at this
point we simply plug in \emph{x = 3} to get $y = (3)^2 - 6(3) = -9$.
Plotting the roots and the minimum on the graph should allow you to
sketch the curve.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Tangent lines that pass through P
\end{itemize}

We know there are two lines. Both pass through the point $(4, -12)$ and
their two slopes are -2 and 6 (from part c). The equation of the two
lines are thus

$y + 12 = -2(x - 4)$

$y + 12 = 6(x -4)$

Or in \emph{y = mx + b} form

$y + 12 = -2x - 4$

$y = 6x -36$

Alternatively, you know that the line with slope -2 passes through P and
the point \emph{(2, f(2)) = (2, -8)}, while the line with slope 6 passes
through P and the point \emph{(6, f(6)) = (6, 0)}. Drawing these points
and then connecting them with lines will also produce the correct
picture.
